top_categories.workout_context: 8,500ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
At mile 60 of 103, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Rebecca's Private Idaho's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before September.
Rebecca's Private Idaho's High desert gravel, Mountain passes forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 103 miles.
83ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At Rebecca's Private Idaho, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 103 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Rebecca's Private Idaho. Train it until it feels boring.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Rebecca's Private Idaho, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
8,500ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on high desert gravel with sustained climbs. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 8,500ft of climbing on high desert gravel with sustained climbs does to your power file on race day.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Rebecca's Private Idaho’s 103 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.altitude: Rebecca's Private Idaho with 8,500ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%. Altitude at 6,000-8,000 feet.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Rebecca's Private Idaho requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on high desert gravel with sustained climbs to build confidence. Expect: high desert gravel, mountain passes, scenic forest roads.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on VO2max, Durability, and Race Simulation to prepare you for 103 miles of high desert gravel with sustained climbs in Ketchum, Idaho.
